Tbe Union of Corinth and Лrgos
243

The further implications of the passage must be discussed presently,  but for the moment it is necessary to notice that beyond all question Xenophon means us to believe here that by the union Corinth had ceased to have an independent existence as a city - state.  But now for the contradictions.  The same Xenophon writing of the first mission of the Spartan Antalcidas to Persia toward the end of this year 592 tells us that the allies thought fit to send missions also.  Ambassadors went to Persia from the Athenians,  and also » from the Boeotians and Corinth and Argos : there was still,  therefore,  an independent government at Corinth.  This fact is further attested by a passage in the speech of Andocides bConceming the Peace with Sparta« ( this same abortive peace of Antalcidas ),  delivered at Athens in the winter 392 / 1.  »The Argives and Corinthians are here present«,  says Andocides,  »and will tell you that it is better to continue the war«,  and he is referring of course to ambassadors of Argos and Corinth ; to Andocides,  Corinth is still Corinth and not part of Argos^®.  Finally,  phon himself commits the crowning indiscretion ( if it is that ).  Referring to the mission of Iphicrates to the Hellespont in 388,  to explain his being
27.  rovç rvQavvevovraç ( MSS ) is printed by Marchant ( Oxford ),  who conjectures perhaps èvlovç for rovç.  Hude ( Teubner ) and Hatzfeld ( Budé ) print the conjecture of Campe rovç <Jv dwa / uei dvraç> rvQavvevovraç.  For the present purpose the difference is immaterial : the persons referred to are the democratic leaders,  whose methods were no doubt distasteful to the oligarchs. 
28.  Xen.  ihid.  IV.  8.  13 : cf.  ibid.  15,  a passage which,  if other evidence were lacking,  might well suggest that the Argives had already got possession of Corinth at this date : —. . . .  0?  t 'Agyetoi,  oij ineOvfiow,  ovx èvofiiCov äv rrjv KôqivOov ôvvaaâai d ) ç
ëxeiv roiovrcDV awerjxœv xai onovÔwv yevofxévcov.  But the evidence contained in the speech of Andocides ( below ) shows that the phrase here oë ènedvfiovv must be given its full value : the possession of Corinth is still a desire,  or a plan,  not yet an shed fact. 
29.  Andoc.  III.  41. 
cf.  ibid.  27.  xsXevovai yàç ( sc.  oi ^Agyeioi ) гцгад xoivfj fierà aq?  ô } v xal fierà KoQivdlcov noKeixeîv. . .  èx yàq rov TioXéfjLov xQoviadévroç KôqivBov éXsîv TZQoaôoxôùOi, . . .  ( i.  e.  they do not yet possess it ). 
ibid.  26.  Iva r^xlv ri yévrjrai ; Iva rixxöiiievoi [ xèv xal r^v oîxelav x^Qav àTtoMacofièv лддд rfj KoQivOicov,  vixYjaavreç ôè tî ) v KoQivOiœv 'Aqyeiœv ^oiijacojuev.  ( i.  e.  Corinthian territory is not yet Argive ). 
ibid.  32.  KoQivBicov ôè rovç vvv êxovTaç тг ) у noXiv. . . .  is a disparaging way of ferring to the democracy at Corinth. 
The date is that of Beloch ; Judeich dates the speech one year earlier ( see note 26 above ).
